newsitem.title: GERMANY: Zeitler says Buba, Bonn close to asset compromise.
newsitem.headline: Zeitler says Buba, Bonn close to asset compromise.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Franz-Christoph Zeitler said on Saturday the central bank and German Finance Minister Theo Waigel were close to a compromise on Bonn's plans to revalue German official reserves.
Speaking on German radio, Zeitler also said he was opposed to a lax interpretation of Maastricht Treaty deficit criteria for nations wanting to join monetary union in 1999.
Zeitler said an asset revaluation compromise was achievable and "lies near."

The Bundesbank and the finance ministry have argued over a plan to revalue currency and gold reserves. The scheme was designed to help Bonn reap a windfall profit, which could be used to pay down debt and help Germany qualify for monetary union.
Zeitler also called for Maastricht criteria to be strictly applied. "It can not be the solution now to turn to a lax interpretation of the three percent criteria," he said.

He refused to comment on the possibility of a delay in the single currency project, but said the timetable was important because it put positive pressure on candidate countries to prepare for monetary union.
